ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: I gave the readings a low rating because I don't know that they truly corresponded to what we were studying. We werent really using a textbook and the readings were not at all addressed in class so seemed mostly unnecessary

I really enjoyed this course overall. I learned a lot putting together the 3 presentations, and really enjoyed the small group feel and discussions. I thought there could have been one less presentation and a little more of Ann's lecturing. It felt like the course was missing a bit of structure, and I think a few more readings would have been helpful.

I believe this course would have been even more useful if a packet was handed out that contained lists of prevalent forest health issues. For example: a couple pages on insects that cause diseases, a couple pages on fungi, a couple pages on the effects of fires, floods, droughts, winds, hurricanes, etc. This would be a 30-50 page packet that could be taken out of class and referenced in the future. There could even be blank templates in the packet that could be filled out by students while listening to classmates' presentations.i LOVED this class!
Question 5: I wish there were more forest health walks where we could see specific forest diseases/invasive species/ stressors.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The emphasis on student presentations was very useful opportunity and provided a wide range of topics to learn about which may not have been otherwise addressed.
The presentations were all so good. This was my favorite course of the year. It was awesome to get to study what I wanted, and learn from what other people were interested in. Fun. Stuff.
Small group discussion and flexibility in choosing presentation topics.

Ann was SO friendly, supportive, and knowledgeable. I really enjoyed her teaching style in this course. The best aspect was having students present three times. These presentations required a lot of planning, research, and practice. Ann's feedback was very helpful.
The flexibility in choosing a topic! I was able to learn exactly what I wanted to, and most student topics focused on issues relevant to today.

Having three presentations was GREAT. I can't say enough about this class design. It allowed me to pursue topics that I'm excited about but also learn what my classmates are interested in. I wish more classes at FES required as many presentations. Public speaking is one of the most useful skills I can learn while at FES.I also really liked having so many outside speakers come in. Always good to hear what's happening on the front lines.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: It seemed like there was heavier application and presentation on certain topics (eg forest fragmentation, ticks& lyme disease) especially with the New England case studies that had similar guest lectures. These may have been an opportunity to branch out more in the topics covered in student presentations if the guest lectures are still occurring.
I never received any feedback on any work I did in this course, which is very disappointing.
The supportive materials. The powerpoints are good but it is hard to study them afterward if you missed class or something - so maybe more informative suppor materials.

I thought there were too few field trips (maybe one more would have been nice, just walking around the woods and talking through general forest health issues), and a little too heavy on the student presentation side. I would have preferred to have 1 less presentation and more of Ann's lecturing. She's so knowledgable and I felt like I didn't benefit from it as much in this course. Perhaps more outside lecturers, also?

Two things. First, the packet I described in question 13 and more field trips. It would have been amazing to see a forest or stand that has serious health issues and be asked to identify what's wrong.
The instructor-led lectures could be boiled down even more. Students tended not to pay attention to talk about taxonomy, but would listen when implications for management came up.
Would be good to have fewer people leaving class early for other classes- it gets distracting.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Great discussions in class. One suggestion is to have the TA or professor give a mock presentation to show the expectations for the presentations.Horrible time management by first years. Hour long presentations etc.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I felt like the focus of the course was perhaps a bit more region-specific than was ideal for my own interests in tropical forestry. While many of the concepts apply broadly, there were a lot of individual case studies that may not be relevant in other settings.
Forest health is important for me because of MF requirements and future forest management work

I wanted to have a better understanding of how various considerations of forest health could be integrated into financial analysis. I actually think having an outside speaker talk about this could be really beneficial to the course overall. It would be interesting to learn more about how to translate these risks into business decision making (as it relates to forestland investing).
As an MF, this course gave great insight into the complex puzzle of forest health. It also gave me the freedom to explore the topics I wanted and to improve presentation skills.

This is the first class I've taken on forest health. It isn't a class I'll point to when talking to employers to prove that I'm an expert on the subject, but it is at least a good exposure. For people not focused on field research but more on policy/communications issues, this is a good biological science credit.
It doesn't really. Just for fun and personal interest!

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Fulfilled a requirement for the MF degree and seemed like a relevant& interesting topic

I<3 Ann Camp and I loved the idea of a student led course. Lots of student led courses end up being ill managed discussion sessions where nobody did the reading. With presentations it is really great to discuss after everybody shares the same material and people are so invested
same reason as above.
I needed another biological science credit for the MF degree, Ann is a great teacher, and I wanted more practice with longer (over 30 minute) presentations.

I took this for personal interest. My community manages some land and I wanted to gain some basic knowledge on forest health so I could be more knowledgeable when working with our forester. This class was extremely useful for this goal.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: (See 17)
Yes!
For the most part, yes. Like I said, a bit more lecturing, outside speakers and technical readings would have been helpful.

Absolutely. I can talk more confidently about forest health issues now, and at least I've heard of most of them now. I think if i were tasked with controlling an invasive species in the future I would at least have some baseline knowledge and the right framework for thinking about regulation.
Yes, certainly.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Take it if you are committed to learning the subject matter and comfortable learning from peers and seminar presentations.
Do it!

Pick your presentation topics based on your personal interests. Bring up questions in class for discussion, and ask Ann lots of questions because she's incredibly knowledgable and responsive to students.
Take it!
Take this class if you have any specific issues you want to personally explore. It was harder for students who couldn't name a forest health problem at the start of the semester

Ann is awesome, definitely take a class or two with her! She really cares about students' skills development (see the public speaking practice) and just makes class relaxed and enjoyable yet informative.
